Package lab4

Class Lab4Utilities

java.lang.Object
lab4.Lab4Utilities
public class Lab4Utilities extends Object
In this lab you will practice writing methods, using classes from the Java Standard Library, and working with String and arrays. This Lab4Utilities class will help you do things with arrays: 1D and 2D This Lab4Utilities class contains a random assortment of methods that should improve your programming skills in using Java Control Structures (selection structures, repetition structures, and nested Loops), 1D and 2D arrays. Hint: You may use java.util.Arrays class.

  • Method Details

    • numberOfEvens

      public static int numberOfEvens(int[] inputarray)
      Implement the method below, which takes an array of int numbers as the input argument and returns the number of even numbers in the array argument. Your code should use a for loop.

      For example: 

       if array1 = {9, 10, 3, 4, 3} then      return 2
 if array1 = { 1, 6, 1}  then  return 1
 if array1 = { 4, 24, 46, 0} then  return 4
 if array1 = { 15, 9, 45, 57}  then  return 0
      Parameters:
      inputarray - : int input array
      Returns:
      returns the number of even numbers in the array argument.

    • avgAreaofRectangeles

      public static double avgAreaofRectangeles(Rectangle[] inputarray)
      Given class Rectangle defined in same package.

      Implement the method below, which takes an array of Rectangle objects as input argument and returns the average area of these rectangle objects.

      You can assume that the input array is not null and contains at least 1 one rectangle object.

      Parameters:
      inputarray - Array of the Rectangle object
      Returns:
      the average area of these rectangle objects.

    • average2D

      public static double average2D(int[][] inputarray)
      Implement the method below, which takes a 2D array of int numbers as input argument and returns the average of its elements.

      You can assume that the input array is not null and contains at least 1 one element.

      For example: 

              if inputarray = {{9, 2, 3, 4}, {1, 2, 3, 45}, {1, 222, 333, -4}} then return 51.75
        if inputarray = {{1, 4}, {12, 42}} then return 14.75
        if inputarray = {{20}, {4, 2, 12}} then return 9.5
        if inputarray = {{81, 28, 4}, {2, 33, -42}, {1, -22,-4}} then return 9.0
      Parameters:
      inputarray - 2D input array of integers
      Returns:
      The average of its elements.

    • minmax2D

      public static int[] minmax2D(int[][] inputarray)
      Implement the method below, which takes a 2D array of int numbers as input argument, then finds its maximum and minimum values and returns a sorted array containing the minimum and maximum values, respectively.

      You can assume that the input array is not null and contains at least two elements.

      For example: 

              if inputarray = {{9, 2, 3, 4}, {1, 2, 3, 45}, {1, 222, 333, -4}} then return [-4, 333]
        if inputarray = {{1, 4}, {12, 42}} then return [1, 42]
        if inputarray = {{20}, {4, 2, 12}} then return [2, 20]
        if inputarray = {{81, 28, 4}, {2, 33, -42}, {1, -22,-4}} then return [-42, 81]
      Parameters:
      inputarray - 2D input array of integers
      Returns:
      A sorted array contains the minimum and maximum values, respectively.

    • averageOfOdd

      public static double averageOfOdd(int[] inputarray)
      This averageOfOdd method receives an array of integers, then calculates the average of the odd elements of this array.

      You can assume that the array is not empty and contains at least 1 one element.

      For example: 

                      if inputarray = {3, 6}   then   return 3.0
                if inputarray = { 1, 1, 1}   then       return 1.0
                if inputarray = { 2, 4, 6, 3}  then     return 3.0
                if inputarray = { 11, 25, 12, 50}  then         return 18.0
      Parameters:
      inputarray - the input array of integers
      Returns:
      the average of the ODD elements of the input array of integers, the average of type double

    • removeDuplicatesElement

      public static int[] removeDuplicatesElement(int[] inputarray)
      Implement the method below that takes an array int as an input argument and returns an array of int containing the unique elements after removing the duplicate elements from the input array. The order of elements in the returned array is unimportant, so the array contains [1, 2, 3] and [3, 2, 1] will be considered similar/same.

      You can assume that the input array is not null and contains at least 1 one element.

      For example: 

              if inputarray = {3,4,4,1,2,3,5,6,7,8}  then return [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]
        if inputarray = {4,2,8,8,9,9,7,8} then return [2, 4, 7, 8, 9]
        if inputarray = {9,2,8,8,9,9,8,8} then return [2, 8, 9]
        if inputarray = {1,1,0,1,8,8} then return [0, 1, 8]
      Parameters:
      inputarray - input array of integer
      Returns:
      array of int contains the unique elements after removing the duplicate elements from the input array

    • isConsecutive

      public static String isConsecutive(int[] inputarray)
      Implement the method below that takes an array of int numbers as input argument and returns String value indicate that all elements belonging to this input array are in a sequence of increasing consecutive integers and returns another String value if not consecutive Consecutive integers are integers that come one after the other, as in 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, etc.

      You can assume that the input array is not empty and contains at least 1 one element.

      For example: 

       if inputarray = {6, 7, 8, 9} then return "{6, 7, 8, 9} is consecutive"
 if inputarray = { 6, 7, 8, 9, 2, 9} then return "{ 6, 7, 8, 9, 2, 9} is NOT consecutive"
 if inputarray = { 1, 1, 1, 1}  then return "{ 1, 1, 1, 1} is NOT consecutive"
 if inputarray = { 2, 3, 4, 5} then return "{ 2, 3, 4, 5} is consecutive"
      Parameters:
      inputarray - input array of integer
      Returns:
      String value, see the above examples

    • countEvenPairs2D

      public static int countEvenPairs2D(int[][] inputarray)
      Implement the method below, which takes a two-dimensional array of integers as the input argument and returns the total number of distinct pairs (a, b) where both a and b are even numbers and a is less than b (a<b ). Your code should use nested for loops.

      For example: 

       if inputarray = { {9, 10, 3, 4, 3}, {1, 6, 2}, {4, 24, 46, 0}, {15, 9, 45, 57} } then return 21
 note we have 21 distinct pairs within this 2D array as follows 
 [0, 2],[0, 4],[0, 6],[0, 10],[0, 24],[0, 46],[2, 4],[2, 6],
 [2, 10],[2, 24],[2, 46],[4, 6],[4, 10],[4, 24],[4, 46],[6, 10],
 [6, 24],[6, 46],[10, 24],[10, 46],[24, 46]
 if inputarray = { {1, 6, 1}, {5, 9, 15, 20}, {23, 33, 99} } then return 1
 if inputarray = { {4, 21, 43, 1}, {22, 32, 42, 52} } then return 10
 if inputarray = { {15, 9, 45, 57}, {13, 17, 23} }then return 0
      Parameters:
      inputarray - 2D int input array
      Returns:
      the number of distinct pairs (a, b) where both a and b are even numbers and a < b.
